Award.AwardTitle: Large Scale Dynamics and Statistics of California Extreme Weather in the Atmosphere and in Global Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will focus on two types of extreme weather events that affect the California Central Valley, viz extreme hot spells, and cold air outbreaks. Both these extreme weather events is associated with very prominent and highly significant patterns of weather variables in the atmosphere. This project will undertake diagnostic analysis of extreme weather events. The diagnostic tools will also be applied to simulations of historical climate by several climate models to assess how well those models simulate large-scale meteorological patterns and evaluate how well each model captures the dynamics needed to create the large-scale meteorological patterns. Simulations of future climate will be analyzed and recalibrated, based on the performance of each model in simulating historical climate, so as to estimate how the properties of each extreme weather event might change in the future

Extreme weather events are of great interest to the agricultural community, to public utilities and their associated regulatory agencies, and to the public in general. Results from this work will be communicated to farmers through the agricultural extension service and various agricultural periodicals. Results will also be shared with the California Energy Commission and with the EnvironMentors chapter, a national program to involve and excite underrepresented youth in environmental studies. Thus the broader impacts of this project are substantial.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined hot spells and cold air outbreaks that affect California’s Central Valley and actually, much of the west coast of the continental US. Both hot spells and cold air outbreaks have been linked to deaths and have caused billions of dollars in damage. Understanding such events and estimating how they may change in the future has great value to society.

     The research looked first at understanding the weather patterns that lead up to the onset of these hot spell and cold air outbreak events.  Then the project examined how well about a dozen climate models simulate the general properties of the hot spell weather patterns. Finally, the projections by these models of future hot spells during 2061-2100 were compared and analyzed.

     The work discovered that the atmosphere has two distinct ways of creating the same pattern that always occurs at the onset of California hot spells. One way is an expansion southward of a pre-existing heat wave in western Canada and the US Pacific Northwest. The other way involves energy transfer across the north Pacific that results in strong sinking off the northwest coast of California, where the sinking causes the air temperature to rise dramatically. Other work showed connections between unusually strong rainfall over western Indonesia region and the subsequent development of one type of hot spell and strong rainfall over the eastern equatorial Pacific and subsequent development of the other type of hot spell.

     The research required some novel techniques be developed and refined, most notably, a way to characterize, with the sign and magnitude of an index, how similar a day’s weather pattern is to the pattern present during historically very strong hot spells. Separately, a pair of indices could distinguish the two types of hot spell events. These three indices allowed a uniform basis on which to assess climate models ability to reproduce California hot spells.

     The cold air outbreak research was limited to understanding what leads up to these events. The sequence of events is more complex than anticipated. The basic parts are ‘ridges’ of higher pressure over Alaska and the southeastern US with a ‘trough’ of lower pressure in between. The Alaskan ridge drives cold air out of Alaska and the southeast US ridge helps direct the cold air towards the US west coast. The Alaskan ridge forms first and is linked to coordinated circulations by a strong western north pacific low pressure system and a separate low over Hawaii. The low over Hawaii is part of a tropical weather pattern having strong rainfall near Hawaii and near western Indonesia.

     The project coined the term ‘LSMP’ analysis to describe the focus on the large scale meteorological patterns (LSMP) associated with such extreme events. To disseminate this approach widely, a lengthy article was published in a major journal describing the LSMP analysis approach for extreme temperature events over North America. The article describes: pros and cons of six statistical methods to find LSMP structures; the theoretical understanding of such LSMPs; how LSMPs are simulated in models; and possible trends. This paper has been popular and should influence how such extreme events are studied and future projections of them interpreted.
